revision.text:
{{Refimprove|date=April 2013}} {{Infobox TV channel| name= LAB HD [[Image:lablog.JPG]] | launch = July 1, 2004 | closed date = Dec 31, 2005 | network = Voom HD Networks | owner = [[Rainbow Media]] | broadcast area = USA on DISH DBS | headquarters = New York City | former names = [[Moov HD]] }}
'''LAB HD''' was a three-year experiment by [[Voom HD Networks]]. It is the only channel in history devoted to video art and experimental film as a continuous flow of ambient television. While it is no longer broadcasting, the channel persists as Voom HD Lab, an outreach effort on the part of its parent company, and it continues to commission pieces from artists and filmmakers.
Voom launched as a DBS (direct broadcast satellite) service in the United States in October 2003. The service offered 21 channels of high-definition video focused on niche audiences. Most of the channels were conventional offerings, but one slot was reserved for an experimental channel called [[Moov HD|MOOV HD]]. The channel was produced by Concrete Pictures, a design and production house in Philadelphia founded by Jeff Boortz. The intent was to produce video art for public consumption. The branding of the channel was elegant, but the content was of uneven quality, and it was derided as "the [[screensaver]] channel."
Voom assigned [[Ali Hossaini]] to serve as executive producer of the channel. He began revamping the programming with high-profile productions, notably a series of "video portraits" directed by Robert Wilson and produced by Noah Khoshbin.<ref>http://www.newsday.com/features/printedition/ny-c5073773feb01,0,1704020.story</ref> New strands of programming were introduced, such as Tank TV and Micro TV. The former featured public aquariums and the latter photomicroscopy in high-definition. Concrete Pictures produced a program called Space, which stitched together footage from NASA into ambient video.
Efforts to transform the channel culminated on January 1, 2004, when it was relaunched as LAB HD, with the tagline, Experiments in High Definition. Hossaini hired filmmaker Lili Chin to manage a new Outreach Program that would put high-definition gear, including cameras and a post-production facility, into the hands of selected artists. Chin succeeded in attracted a range of talent from the orbit of Anthology Film Archives. LAB HD has deep connections to [[Anthology Film Archives]], where Lili Chin curates film programs and [[Ali Hossaini]] serves on the Board of Advisors.<ref>http://www.transmag.org/mailer/mailer26/ Trans News</ref>
During 2005 LAB HD productions thrived. Director [[Robert Wilson (director)|Robert Wilson]] produced avant-garde video pieces with [[Brad Pitt]], [[Winona Ryder]], [[Jeanne Moreau]], among others.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://broadcastengineering.com/hdtv/hd_still_life_artist_wilson_1227/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2007-02-20 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070315053312/http://broadcastengineering.com/hdtv/hd_still_life_artist_wilson_1227/ |archivedate=2007-03-15 |df= }}</ref> Hossaini also collaborated with Sandra Antelo-Suarez of Trans Gallery on her project, ''Don’t Trust Anyone Over 30'', a rock and roll puppet show conceived by Dan Graham. Originally staged with live puppets at Miamia Basel,<ref>http://artdaily.com/news/11724/Don-t-Trust-Anyone-Over-Thirty-by-Dan-Graham#.VwMLxRMrLsk Art Daily News</ref> a video version of the show was directed by [[Tony Oursler]] for the 2006 Whitney Biennial.<ref>http://whitney.org/www/2006biennial/artists.php?artist=DTAOT Whitney</ref> The Museum of the Moving Image put LAB HD on permanent exhibit as well.<ref>http://www.amcnetworks.com/press-releases/vooms-equator-hd-names-ali-hossaini-executive-producer AMC Networks</ref>
Unfortunately LAB HD did not meet the criteria to survive as a commercial channel. It had been conceived as an ambient channel, and, in his notes, Hossaini refers to [[Jerry Mander]]'s book ''[[Four Arguments for the Elimination of Television]]'' as a model for the channel. The channel was a continuous flow of non-narrative images and sounds, mostly music. It was meant to provoke reflection not distraction. This presented a weak value proposition from a marketing standpoint, and, on January 1, 2006, it was replaced by another innovative format, a video gaming channel that has garnered considerably more attention (outside the art world).
Voom HD Networks decided to keep the Outreach Program under the name Voom HD Lab, with [[Ali Hossaini]] as executive producer and Lili Chin as associate producer. Voom HD Lab has supported the work of numerous artists and filmmakers, many of whom had never worked in high-definition video. LAB productions appeared in numerous museums, film festivals and galleries.
== Exhibitions == * ''Ace Gallery Los Angeles <ref>http://acegallery.net/artist/robert-wilson/ ACE Gallery</ref> * ''Paula Cooper Gallery <ref>https://www.nytimes.com/2007/01/30/arts/design/30wils.html?_r=1&oref=slogin</ref> * ''Philips de Pury Gallery * ''2006 Whitney Biennial <ref>http://whitney.org/www/2006biennial/artists.php?artist=DTAOT Whitney Biennial</ref> * ''P.S. 1/MoMA <ref>http://www.moma.org/learn/resources/archives/ps1_artists/artists_w2#Art6574 PS 1/MoMA</ref> * ''Couvent de Cordeliers (Paris) * ''2006 Tribeca Film Festival <ref>http://nymag.com/movies/features/16877/ NY Magazine</ref> * ''Anthology Film Archives <ref>http://www.transmag.org/mailer/mailer26/ Trans News</ref> * ''Alona Kagan Gallery * ''Monkey Town

{{Refimprove|date=July 2010}} {{Main|Avant Garde}} [[File:Pablo picasso 1.jpg|thumb|250px|[[Pablo Picasso]] 1962]] '''Avant-garde''' ({{IPA-fr|avɑ̃ ɡaʁd}}) is [[French language|French]] for "vanguard".<ref name="dictref">{{Cite web|url=http://dictionary.reference.com/search?q=avant-garde|title=Avant-garde definitions|accessdate=2007-03-14|publisher=Lexico Publishing Group, LLC|work=Dictionary.com}}</ref> The term is commonly used in French, English, and German to refer to people or works that are [[experiment]]al or innovative, particularly with respect to [[art]] and [[culture]].
Avant-garde represents a pushing of the boundaries of what is accepted as the [[Norm (sociology)|norm]] or the [[status quo]], primarily in the cultural realm. The notion of the existence of the avant-garde is considered by some to be a hallmark of [[modernism]], as distinct from [[postmodernism]]. Postmodernism posits that the age of the constant pushing of boundaries is no longer with us and that avant-garde has little to no applicability in the age of [[Postmodern art]].
==Avant Garde: Visual artists== [[File:Portrait of Henri Matisse 1933 May 20.jpg|thumb|[[Henri Matisse]], 1933, photo by [[Carl Van Vechten]]]] [[File:Portrait of Joan Miro, Barcelona 1935 June 13.jpg|thumb|[[Joan Miró]] 1935, photo by Carl Van Vechten]] [[File:Edward Steichen - Brancusi.jpg|thumb|[[Constantin Brâncuși]], 1922, photo by [[Edward Steichen]]]] * [[Pierre Alechinsky]] ([[Belgium|Belgian]] artist, member of [[COBRA (avant-garde movement)|CoBrA]]) * [[Alexander Archipenko]] (Ukrainian sculptor) * [[Magdalena Abakanowicz]] (Polish sculptor) * [[Hans Bellmer]] (German artist) * [[Joseph Beuys]] (German artist)<ref>See Claudia Schmuckli: ‘Chronology and Selected Exhibition History,’ in Joseph Beuys: Actions, Vitrines, Environments (Tate, 2005).This account of Beuys’s biography is indebted to Schmuckli’s chronology.</ref> * [[Francisco Bores]] (Spanish painter) * [[Constantin Brâncuși]] (Romanian sculptor)<ref name=brainjuice>[http://www.brain-juice.com/cgi-bin/show_bio.cgi?p_id=108 "Constantin Brancusi"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061220115258/http://www.brain-juice.com/cgi-bin/show_bio.cgi?p_id=108 |date=2006-12-20 }} at brainjuice.com. (Accessed March 27, 2007.)</ref> * [[Georges Braque]] (French painter)<ref>[http://www.artcyclopedia.com/artists/braque_georges.html Artcyclopedia] - Links to Braque's works and information</ref> * [[David Burliuk]] (Russian painter, illustrator) * [[Wladimir Burliuk]] (illustrator, [[Jack of Diamonds (artists)|Jack of Diamonds]]) * [[Giorgio de Chirico]] (painter)<ref>Giorgio de Chirico in the [[Museum of Modern Art]]</ref> * [[Joseph Csaky]] (Hungarian-French sculptor) * [[Salvador Dalí]] (Spanish painter) * [[Theo van Doesburg]] (Dutch artist) the founder of [[De Stijl]].<ref name="tate">{{cite web |url=http://www.tate.org.uk/learn/online-resources/glossary/d/de-stijl |title=De Stijl |accessdate=2006-07-31 |work=Tate Glossary |publisher=The Tate}}</ref><ref name="archdic">{{cite book |last=Curl |first=James Stevens |title=A Dictionary of Architecture and Landscape Architecture |year=2006 |edition=Second |publisher=Oxford University Press |isbn=0-19-860678-8}}</ref> * [[Jean Dubuffet]] (French painter)<ref>[http://www.moma.org/collection/artist.php?artist_id=1633 Jean Dubuffet at the Museum of Modern Art (MoMA)]</ref> * [[Marcel Duchamp]] (French artist)<ref>Calvin Tomkins: ''Duchamp: A Biography''.</ref> * [[Naum Gabo]] (sculptor)<ref>[http://www.tate.org.uk/research/researchservices/archive/ Naum Gabo at the Tate Gallery Archive]</ref> * [[Pablo Gargallo]] (Spanish sculptor) * [[Paul Gauguin]](P GO)<ref>[http://www.moma.org/collection/artist.php?artist_id=2098]</ref> * [[Alberto Giacometti]] (sculptor)<ref>James Lord (1997) ''Giacometti: A Biography'', Farrar, Straus and Giroux* Alberto Giacometti. Kunsthaus Zürich, 2001; New York, The Museum of Modern Art, 2001-2002.</ref> * [[Albert Gleizes]] (French painter and theorist) * [[Julio González (sculptor)|Julio González]] (Spanish sculptor)<ref>[http://www.guggenheimcollection.org/site/artist_bio_55.html Guggenheim Museum biography] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080509075353/http://www.guggenheimcollection.org/site/artist_bio_55.html |date=2008-05-09 }}</ref> * [[Natalia Goncharova]] (Russian painter) * [[Arshile Gorky]] (painter) * [[George Grosz]] (German painter) * [[Neil Harbisson]] (English artist) * [[Asger Jorn]] (Danish artist, member of CoBrA) * [[Wassily Kandinsky]] (Russian artist)<ref>Hajo Düchting. ''Wassily Kandinsky 1866–1944: A Revolution in Painting''. (Taschen, 2000). {{ISBN|3-8228-5982-6}}</ref> * [[Allan Kaprow]] (painter/happenings)<ref name ="ART IN REVIEW">{{Cite news | last =Cotter | first =Holland | publication-date =November 19, 1999 | title =ART IN REVIEW; Allan Kaprow and Robert Watts -- 'Experiments in the Everyday' | periodical =The New York Times | url =https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9C03E5D6173CF93AA25752C1A96F958260&fta=y | accessdate =2008-04-29 | postscript =<!--None--> }}</ref> * [[Roger Kemp]] (Pioneer Australian abstractionist) * [[Frederick John Kiesler]] (designer), (sculptor), (visual artist) * [[Willem de Kooning]] (painter)<ref>[http://www.britannica.com/eb/article-9029596/Willem-de-Kooning Willem de Kooning, Britannica.com, p1]</ref> * [[Yayoi Kusama]] (Japanese artist and writer) * [[Fernand Léger]] (painter) * [[El Lissitzky]] (Russian artist)<ref>{{cite book |author1=Mayakovsky, Vladimir |author2=El Lissitzky | title=For the Voice (Dlia golosa) | publisher=The MIT Press | year=2000 | isbn=0-262-13377-6}}</ref> * [[Kazimir Malevich]] (Ukrainian artist)<ref>[http://www.guggenheimcollection.org/site/artist_bio_94.html Guggenheim: Kazimir Malevich]</ref> * [[Agnes Martin]] (painter)<ref>http://www.moma.org/collection/browse_results.php?criteria=O%3AAD%3AE%3A3787</ref> * [[Henri Matisse]] (painter)<ref>[[Hilary Spurling]]. Bloomsbury, London. {{ISBN|0-7475-0557-8}}</ref> * [[Claes Oldenburg]] (sculptor)<ref>[http://www.guggenheimcollection.org/site/artist_bio_121.html Oldenburg Biography at the Guggenheim Museum] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20031007023116/http://www.guggenheimcollection.org/site/artist_bio_121.html |date=2003-10-07 }}</ref> * [[Yoko Ono]] (Japanese-American sculptor/installation artist/musician) * [[Francis Picabia]] (painter) * [[Pablo Picasso]] (Spanish painter and sculptor) * [[Antoine Pevsner]] (sculptor) * [[Jackson Pollock]] (painter)<ref name=iha>Piper, David. ''The Illustrated History of Art'', {{ISBN|0-7537-0179-0}}, p460-461.</ref> * [[Robert Rauschenberg]] (painter)<ref name="Retrospective"> {{cite news |url = http://www.csmonitor.com/durable/1997/11/28/feat/arts.1.html |title = Rauschenberg's Signature on the Century |work = [[Christian Science Monitor]] |date = 28 November 1997 |author = Marlena Donohue |quote = Rauschenberg's mammoth career [[retrospective]] at the [[Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum]] (and other New York sites) from Sept. 19 to Jan. 7, 1998… along with longtime friends pre-[[Pop Art|Pop]] painter [[Jasper Johns]] and the late conceptual composer [[John Cage]], Rauschenberg pretty much defined the technical and philosophic art landscape and its offshoots after [[Abstract Expressionism]]. |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20060707213354/http://www.csmonitor.com/durable/1997/11/28/feat/arts.1.html |archivedate = 7 July 2006 |df = }}</ref> * [[Man Ray]] (painter and visual artist) * [[Ad Reinhardt]] (painter)<ref>[http://www.guggenheimcollection.org/site/artist_bio_133A.html Ad Reinhardt bio at Guggenheim Museum site] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20050207085440/http://www.guggenheimcollection.org/site/artist_bio_133A.html |date=2005-02-07 }}</ref> * [[Jean-Paul Riopelle]] (Canadian artist) * [[Alexander Rodchenko]] (Russian artist) * [[Olga Rozanova]] (Russian artist) * [[Kurt Schwitters]] (German artist) * [[David Smith (sculptor)|David Smith]] (sculptor) * [[Kenneth Snelson]] (sculptor) * [[Frank Stella]] (painter)<ref>[http://www.guggenheimcollection.org/site/artist_bio_148.html Frank Stella Biography, Guggenheim Museum] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060427105951/http://www.guggenheimcollection.org/site/artist_bio_148.html |date=2006-04-27 }}</ref> * [[Vladimir Tatlin]] (Russian artist) * [[Sergei Mikhailovich Tretyakov|Sergei Tretyakov]] (Russian artist) * [[Remedios Varo]] (Mexican-Spanish painter) * [[Wolf Vostell]] (German Artist)<ref>[https://archive.is/20120530142236/http://www.museenkoeln.de/homepage/bild-der-woche.asp?bdw=1997_18 Wolf Vostell at the Museum Ludwig in Cologne]</ref> * [[Andy Warhol]] (American painter and director)<ref>[http://www.moma.org/collection/browse_results.php?criteria=O%3AAD%3AE%3A6246&page_number=1&template_id=6&sort_order=1 Andy Warhol at the Museum of Modern Art (MoMA)]</ref> * [[Wols]] (German painter and photographer)

revision.text:
{{Italic title}} '''''Loc. cit.''''' ([[Latin language|Latin]], short for '''''loco citato''''', meaning "in the place cited") is a [[footnote]] or [[endnote]] term used to repeat the title and page number for a given work (and author). ''Loc. cit.'' is used in place of [[ibid.]] when the reference is not only to the work immediately preceding, but also refers to the same page. Therefore, ''loc. cit.'' is never followed by volume or page numbers. ''Loc. cit.'' may be contrasted with ''[[op. cit.]]'' (''opere citato'', "in the work cited"), in which reference is made to a work previously cited, but to a different page within that work. ==Sample usage== * Example 1:
9. R. Millan, "Art of Latin grammar" (Academic, New York, 1997), p. 23.
10. ''Loc. cit.''
In the above example, the ''loc. cit.'' in reference #10 refers to reference #9 in its entirety, including page number. Note that ''loc. cit.'' is capitalized in this instance. * Example 2:
9. R. Millan, "Art of Latin grammar" (Academic, New York, 1997), p. 23.
10. G. Wiki, "Blah and its uses" (Blah Ltd., Old York, 2000), p. 12.
11. Millan, ''loc. cit.''
In the second example, the ''loc. cit.'' in reference #11 refers to reference #9, including page number. ==See also== * [[Bibliography]] * [[Ibid.]] * [[Op. cit.]] * [[MLA style]] ==References== *[http://www.olinda.com/Art/footnotes.htm Conventions in footnoting for essays, papers and books] by Werner Hammerstingl, 1998. *[http://www.nongnu.org/bibulus/bibcit.html Introduction to bibliographies and citation styles] [[Category:Bibliography]] [[Category:Latin literary phrases]]

'''Manasology''' (кyrgyz. ''Манастаануу'') is a separate line of research within Kyrgyz studies, which looks into the scientific study of the Kyrgyz [[Manas epic]]. Representatives of this [[scientific]] area are called ''manasologists''.
==Periods of development== Scientific research of the epic began in the second half of the XIX century by Ch. [[Valikhanov]] and V. [[Radlov]]. Valikhanov had recorded one of the episodes ("Pominki po Kyokyotoyu") in 1856 and partially translated it into Russian. The texts published by Radlov in 1885 in St. Petersburg (in Kyrgyz and German languages) occupy 12,454 lines (including 9449 lines about "Manas")<ref>{{cite book|last1=Karalaev|first1=Sayakbai|title=Manas|date=1984|location=Frunze|url=https://bilim.akipress.org/lib/book:333/manas-po-variantu-sayakbaya-karalaeva-kniga-1-frunze-1984g/?from=bilim&place=type|accessdate=6 May 2018}}</ref>. Full record of the texts of the "Manas" [[trilogy]] has been carried out since 1920, however, fixing versions by [[manaschi]], let alone their full publication are still far from complete.
Kazakh writer M.O. Auezov wrote the first work after Chokan Valikhanov’s works, a monograph on the Kyrgyz "[[Epic of Manas|Manas]]" epic, by creating of a free version of his texts. Monuments were erected for both Kazakh researchers in the [[Bishkek]] city. Among the [[Russian scientists]] who studied the epic, V. Radlov should be noted (the author of the first Russian translation of fragments of the epic), P. Falev (the author of the first [[Soviet]] study on "Manas" - articles "How the Kara-Kygyz epic is built") and S. [[Malov]].
The All-Union Scientific Conference of 1952 in [[Bishkek|Frunze]] came to the conclusion that the epic "is folk in its basis"<ref>{{cite book|last1=Karalayev|first1=Sayakbai|title=Manas II|date=1984|location=Frunze|accessdate=6 May 2018}}</ref>.
Among the translators of the epic into Russian are S. [[Lipkin]], L. [[Penkovsky]], M. Tarlovskiy and others. The largest Russian translation (prosaic) is in 4 volumes so far by A.S. Mirbadaleva and N. V. Kydaish-Pokrovskaya for a bilingual edition in the series "Epic of the Peoples of the USSR" (1984-1995), covers about 50 thousand lines (according to S.Orozbakov).
The first one who played the "Manas" epic in [[Russian language]] in the translations of E. [[Polivanov]], L. [[Penkovsky]], M. Tarlevsky and S. [[Lipkin]], is a national artist of Kyrgyzstan Valery Rovinsky.
Abbreviated versions of the epic exist in [[Kazakh language]] (4 volumes in M. Auezov's presentation, including 2 parts about Manas and the part about Semetey and Seytek) and in [[Uzbek language]] (the poet Mirtemir); separate episodes were translated into German, Hungarian, English and other languages.
==Scientific institutions== The main center of manasology is the National Center for Manasology and Art Culture of the National Academy of Sciences of the [[Kyrgyz Republic]] (director - Akmataliev, Abdyldazhan Amanturovich).
==References== {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Kyrgyz-language literature]] [[Category:Manaschis]] [[Category:Folklore]]

revision.text:
'''Mono-ha''' (もの派) is the name given to a group of 20th-century Japanese artists. The Mono-ha artists explored the encounter between natural and industrial materials, such as stone, steel plates, glass, light bulbs, cotton, sponge, paper, wood, wire, rope, leather, oil, and water, arranging them in mostly unaltered, ephemeral states. The works focus as much on the interdependency of these various elements and the surrounding space as on the materials themselves.
==Origin of the Term “Mono-ha” and its Members==
“Mono-ha” is usually translated in a literal manner, as “School of Things.” The Mono-ha artists regularly assert that “Mono-ha” was a term disparagingly coined by critics (specifically Teruo Fujieda and Toshiaki Minemura in ''Bijutsu Techo'' magazine in 1973) well after they had begun to exhibit their work, and they did not begin as an organized collective. Many of the Mono-ha artists were first exhibited at Tamura and Maki Galleries in Tokyo owned by Nobuo[[(Shinro) Yamagiishi]] who was also an art writer and whose archives are in the collection of [[The National Art Center Tokyo]].
Toshiaki Minemura explains in his 1986 essay “What Was Mono-ha?,” that in terms of their academic background and intellectual exchange, the Mono-ha artists are divided into three groups:<ref>Minemura, Toshiaki. [https://www.kamakura.gallery/mono-ha/minemura-en.html "What was MONO-HA?"], ''MONO-HA'', Kamakura Gallery, 1986, p.6</ref>
# '''"The [[Lee Ufan|Lee]] + [[Tama Art University|Tamabi]] Connection.”''' This comprises [[Nobuo Sekine]], [[Kishio Suga]], Shingo Honda, Katsuhiko Narita and Katsurō Yoshida in the painting department, and [[Susumu Koshimizu]] in the sculpture department at [[Tama Art University]] (aka Tamabi) as well as [[Jiro Takamatsu]] and [[Lee Ufan]], a Korean artist who is a close friend of Sekine. # '''“The [[Tokyo University of the Arts|Geidai Connection]],”''' a group of artists around [[Kōji Enokura]] and Noboru Takayama, who were both graduates of the [[Tokyo University of the Arts]] (aka Geidai), and Hiroshi Fujii and Makoto Habu, who were involved in Mono-ha later on. # '''“The [[Nihon University|Nichidai]] Connection,”''' students from the [[Nihon University]] (aka Nichidai) Fine Arts Department—whose central figure was Noriyuki Haraguchi—also known as the “Yokosuka Group,” due to Haraguchi’s upbringing in Yokosuka and his critique of the local US military presence through his work.<ref>''Kishio Suga''. Los Angeles: Blum & Poe, 2012, p.8</ref>
==Socio-Political Context==
Mono-ha emerged in response to a number of social, cultural and political precedents set in the 1960s. With the exception of Lee Ufan, who was a decade older, most of the Mono-ha artists were just beginning their careers when the violent student protests of 1968–69 occurred.
At the same time, there was much protest against the second extension of the US-Japan Security Treaty (known in abbreviated Japanese as ''[[Anpo]]'') in 1970, binding Japan into providing logistical support for the US war in Vietnam. Coupled with demands for the reversion of [[Okinawa]] by 1972 and the removal of nuclear weapons based there, the climate of protest during this period was symptomatic of a growing distrust of the United States’ intentions towards Asia and its dominant position in the bilateral relationship with Japan. The activism of the “''Anpo'' generation” gave rise to a highly intellectual counterculture that was both critical of US “[[imperialism]]” and acutely self-aware of its Japanese identity.<ref>Munroe, Alexandra. ''Japanese Art After 1945: Scream Against the Sky''. Harry N. Abrams Inc, 1994. p.215</ref>
The Mono-ha artists typically deny involvement with student activist movements at the time, though it is thought that the tense political climate influenced their work, allowing them to grapple with and make sense of their unease and disillusionment with postwar modernity in their different ways.
==Recent Attention in the United States==
In 2012, [[Blum & Poe]] gallery introduced the Mono-ha art into the US with the survey exhibition “Requiem for the Sun: The Art of Mono-ha,” curated by Mika Yoshitake. The gallery has also held solo exhibitions of [[Lee Ufan]], [[Kishio Suga]], [[Susumu Koshimizu]], [[Koji Enokura]], and [[Nobuo Sekine]].
==Phase-Mother Earth== {{Infobox artwork | image_file = | painting_alignment = | image_size = | title = Phase-Mother Earth | alt = | other_language_1 = | other_title_1 = | other_language_2 = | other_title_2 = | artist = Nobuo Sekine | year = 1968, 2008 and 2012 | type = [[earth art]] | height_metric = 2.7 | width_metric = 2.2 | length_metric = | height_imperial = | width_imperial = | length_imperial = | diameter_metric = 2.2 | diameter_imperial = | dimensions = | metric_unit = m| imperial_unit = in<!--don't leave this parameter blank—either don't include it, or include the default in. Not including it will default it to in.--> | italic title = no | city = [[Kobe]], [[Suma Rikyu Park]] | museum = | coordinates = <!-- Only use for the exact coordinates of the artwork itself (and only where known) and not for the coordinates of the museum. Leave blank if coordinates are not known. --> | owner = }}
[[Nobuo Sekine]]'s '''Phase-Mother Earth''' is considered to be the initial work of the Mono-ha movement.<ref>{{cite news |title=Series: 1000 artworks to see before you die |first= |last= |url= https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2008/oct/30/sargent-saxon-serrano?INTCMP=SRCH|newspaper=[[The Guardian]] |date=30 October 2008 |accessdate=2 August 2011}}</ref> Originally created in Suma Rikyu Park in [[Kobe]], and without official permission. The work was re-created in 2008<ref>{{cite journal |last1= Rawlings|first1=Ashley|year= 2008|title=Nobuo Sekine's "Phase-Mother Earth" Under Reconstruction |journal=Art Space Tokyo |volume= |issue= October 28|pages= |publisher= |doi= |url= http://artspacetokyo.com/blog/archives/nobuo_sekines_phase_mother_earth_under_reconstruction/ |accessdate= 31 July 2011}}</ref> and 2012. It was a large cylindrical tower made of packed earth, which was removed from a cylindrical hole with the same shape.
==Members== *[[Jiro Takamatsu]] *[[Nobuo Sekine]] *[[Lee Ufan]] *[[Kishio Suga]] *[[Koji Enokura]] *[[Susumu Koshimizu]] *[[Noboru Takayama]] *[[Katsuhiko Narita]] *[[Noriyuki Haraguchi]] *[[Katsuro Yoshida]] *[[Kenji Inumaki]] *[[Shingo Honda]]
==Bibliography==
*''Japon des avant gardes: 1910–1970''. Paris: Centre Georges Pompidou, 1986. *Chong, Doryun. ''Tokyo 1955–1970: A New Avant-Garde''. New York: Museum of Modern Art, 2012. *Koplos, Janet. ''Contemporary Japanese Sculpture''. New York: Abbeville Press, 1991. *Munroe, Alexandra. ''Japanese Art After 1945: Scream Against the Sky''. New York: Harry N. Abrams Inc, 1994. *Yoshitake, Mika. ''Requiem for the Sun: The Art of Mono-ha''. Los Angeles: Blum & Poe, 2012. *''Kishio Suga''. Los Angeles: Blum & Poe, 2012
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Japanese artists]] [[Category:Contemporary artists]] [[Category:Modern sculptors]] [[Category:Japanese sculptors]] [[Category:Tama Art University alumni]] [[Category:Art movements]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox Museum |name = Museum Conservation Institute |image = |caption = |imagesize = |map_type = |latitude = |longitude = |established = 1963 |location = [[Suitland, Maryland]] |type = |visitors = |director = [http://newsdesk.si.edu/about/bios/robert-j-koestler Robert J. Koestler] |curator = |publictransit= [[Suitland (Washington Metro)|Suitland]] |website = http://www.si.edu/mci/ }}
The [[Smithsonian Institution|Smithsonian's]] '''Museum Conservation Institute'''<ref>[http://newsdesk.si.edu/factsheets/museum-conservation-institute Museum Conservation Institute Fact Sheet]</ref> (MCI) aims to be the center for specialized [[Conservation-restoration|conservation]] and technical collection [[research]] for all of the Smithsonian museums<ref>[http://newsdesk.si.edu/factsheets/facts-about-smithsonian-institution Smithsonian Institution Fact Sheet]</ref> and collections.<ref>[http://newsdesk.si.edu/factsheets/fact-sheet-smithsonian-collections Smithsonian Collections Fact Sheet]</ref> MCI's staff combine state-of-the-art instrumentation and scientific techniques with the knowledge of materials and the history of technology to provide technical research studies and interpretation of art, as well as historical and anthropological objects, to improve the conservation and collections storage capabilities at the Smithsonian. For the majority of the Smithsonian collections, MCI is the only Smithsonian resource for technical studies and analyses.
==History==
The Smithsonian's Board of Regents<ref>[http://newsdesk.si.edu/factsheets/smithsonian-board-regents Smithsonian Board of Regents Fact Sheet]</ref> established the Conservation Research Laboratory of the United States National Museum in 1963 in response to a growing need to support conservation of the entire Institution's collections.
In 1965 the name of the laboratory was changed to the Conservation Analytical Laboratory (CAL). In 1983, the laboratory moved to the Museum Support Center<ref>[http://newsdesk.si.edu/factsheets/museum-support-center Museum Support Center Fact Sheet]</ref> in Suitland, Maryland. Congress mandated a national conservation training program among other wider responsibilities including an expanded conservation science research program.
The Board of Regents approved a name change to the Smithsonian Center for Materials Research and Education (SCMRE) in 1998. SCMRE's mission was to serve all museum communities - national and international, and provide professional training and education programs.
In 2006 the Board of Regents approved the name change to the Museum Conservation Institute (MCI).
==Directors== Robert J. Koestler,<ref>[http://newsdesk.si.edu/about/bios/robert-j-koestler Robert J. Koestler]</ref> 2004-
Lambertus van Zelst, 1984–2003
Robert M. Organ, 1967–1983
Charles H. Olin, 1966–1967
==Facilities==
MCI's laboratories are equipped with advanced analytical instrumentation,<ref>[http://www.si.edu/mci/english/about_mci/facilities/index.html MCI Instrumentation]</ref> including:
* isotope ratio (or stable isotope) mass spectrometry<ref>[http://newsdesk.si.edu/releases/scientists-determine-geese-involved-hudson-river-plane-crash-were-migratory Hudson River Plane Crash]</ref><ref>[http://www.si.edu/mci/irms/index.htm MCI's IRMS Facilities]</ref> * inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry * Fourier transform infrared spectrometry * Raman spectrometry, including Fourier transform Raman and portable Raman spectroscopy * gas chromatography * pyrolysis-gas chromatography-mass spectrometry * optical microscopy<ref>[http://www.si.edu/mci/ImagingStudio/index.html MCI's Imaging Studio] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101013191017/http://www.si.edu/mci/ImagingStudio/index.html |date=2010-10-13 }}</ref> * proteomics <ref>[http://www.si.edu/mci/english/research/technical_studies/ProteomicsResearch.html MCI's Proteomics Research]</ref> * scanning electron microscopy with X-ray and energy dispersive fluorescence * X-ray radiography * ultraviolet-visible light spectrophotometry * structured 3-D color scanning of objects<ref>[http://www.si.edu/MCIImagingStudio MCI's Imaging Studio]</ref>
The Smithsonian's Museum Conservation Institute and the Institut Photonique d’Analyse Non-destructive Européen des Matériaux Anciens platform at Soleil have formed a partnership to use the power of the third-generation synchrotron to study and preserve the priceless Smithsonian collections.<ref>[http://newsdesk.si.edu/releases/smithsonian-and-synchrotron-soleil-join-analyze-antiquities-cultural-heritage-materials Smithsonian and SOLEIL Synchrotron]</ref>
==Further reading== *Charola, A. Elena, and Robert J. Koestler, eds. [http://www.sil.si.edu/smithsoniancontributions/museumconservation/sc_RecordSingle.cfm?filename=scmc-0001 ''Pesticide Mitigation in Museum Collections: Science in Conservation: Proceedings from the MCI Workshop Series'']. Smithsonian Contributions to Museum Conservation, no. 1. Washington, D.C.: Smithsonian Institution Scholarly Press, 2010. Copies of this volume are available for free pdf download by clicking on the included link. *Charola, A. Elena, Christopher McNamara, and Robert J. Koestler, eds. [http://si-pddr.si.edu/dspace/handle/10088/16617 '' Biocolonization of Stone: Control and Preventive Methods: Proceedings from the MCI Workshop Series'']. Smithsonian Contributions to Museum Conservation, no. 2. Washington, DC: Smithsonian Institution Scholarly Press, 2011. Copies of this volume are available for free pdf download by clicking on the included link.
==References== <references/>
==External links== * [http://www.si.edu/mci/ Museum Conservation Institute] Official Museum Conservation Institute web site. * [http://research.si.edu/ Smithsonian Research Online] Smithsonian Research Bibliography and Smithsonian Digital Repository.
{{Smithsonian Institution}}
{{authority control}}
[[Category:Museum organizations]] [[Category:Smithsonian Institution research programs]] [[Category:Conservation and restoration organizations]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2016}} {{Use Australian English|date=November 2016}} '''Naomi Stead''' is an architectural academic, scholar and critic, based in Melbourne, Australia. She is currently the Head of the Architecture Department at [[Monash University Faculty of Art Design & Architecture]], Australia.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|title = Dr Naomi Stead|url = https://www.monash.edu/mada/about-us/people/academic-staff/naomi-stead|website = monash.edu/mada|accessdate = 2018-03-08}}</ref>
== Early years and education == Naomi Stead was born in February, 1975, and grew up in [[Adelaide]], South Australia. She studied architecture at the Louise Laybourne School of Architecture, [[University of South Australia]], graduating with a Bachelor of Architecture with first class honours in 1998. Stead's PhD, ‘On the Object of the Museum and its Architecture’, was conferred by [[University of Queensland|The University of Queensland]] in 2004.<ref>{{Cite web|title = On the object of the museum and its architecture|url = http://espace.library.uq.edu.au/view/UQ:106696|website = espace.library.uq.edu.au|date = 2004-01-01|accessdate = 2015-11-14|first = Stead,|last = Naomi}}</ref>
== Academic career == Stead began her academic career at the [[University of Technology Sydney|University of Technology, Sydney]] (2001–2009) and became a research fellow at the Research Centre ATCH (Architecture Theory Criticism History), University of Queensland in 2009, later becoming a senior research fellow. In 2015 she took up an academic position as Associate Professor at the School of Architecture, University of Queensland.<ref name=":0" /> Stead has also undertaken a number of research fellowships, including Postdoctoral Fellow, Advanced Cultural Studies Institute of Sweden, [[Linköping University|Linkoping University]] (October 2007 – February 2008), and Honorary Visiting Scholar, School of Architecture, [[Katholieke Universiteit Leuven|Catholic University of Leuven]], Belgium (June – December 2005).
Stead describes her academic research as engaged with the following areas: * the history, theory and writing of architectural criticism; experimental writing in architecture; * representations of architects and architecture in popular media * the material culture of the architectural workplace; visual sociology in architecture; * gender equity in architectural practice; feminist architecture theory; women in architecture; * urban cultural geography and walking as an aesthetic practice; tourist culture in cities; * thing theory, artefactuality, and objecthood in architecture; miniaturisation in architecture; Stead was a researcher with John Macarthur on the project The Cultural Logic of Queensland Architecture: Place, Taste and Economy.<ref>{{Cite web|title = The Cultural Logic of Queensland Architecture: Place, Taste and Economy - UQ Researchers|url = http://researchers.uq.edu.au/research-project/12477|website = researchers.uq.edu.au|accessdate = 2015-11-14}}</ref>
=== Equity and Diversity in the Australian Architecture Profession: women, work and leadership === Stead initiated and led the [[Australian Research Council]] funded project Equity and Diversity in the Australian Architecture Profession: Women, Work and Leadership (2011–2014).<ref>{{Cite web|title = Equity and Diversity in the Australian Architecture Profession: Women, Work, and Leadership - Architecture Theory Criticism History - The University of Queensland, Australia|url = http://atch.architecture.uq.edu.au/equity-and-diversity-australian-architecture-profession-women-work-and-leadership|website = atch.architecture.uq.edu.au|accessdate = 2015-11-14}}</ref> This involved eight researchers – Stead, [[Karen Burns (academic)|Karen Burns]], [[Justine Clark]], [[Gill Matthewson]], [[Amanda Roan]], [[Gillian Whitehouse]], [[Julie Willis]] and [[Sandra Kaji-O'Grady]] – and sought map women’s participation in the architectural profession in Australia, to understand why women are under-represented at senior management level, and to identify concrete strategies for change. The project resulted in scholarly publications and in the advocacy and activism project [[Parlour: women, equity, architecture]].<ref>{{Cite web|title = Parlour - women, equity, architecture.|url = http://archiparlour.org/|website = archiparlour.org|accessdate = 2015-11-14}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title = Gender equality: Reading between the lines|url = http://architectureau.com/articles/gender-equality/|website = ArchitectureAU|accessdate = 2015-11-14|first = Michael|last = Smith}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|title = Equity: not just Parlour talk|url = http://www.theage.com.au/national/education/voice/equity-not-just-parlour-talk-20140602-39eh2.html|newspaper = The Age|date = 2014-06-10|access-date = 2015-11-14|first = Niamh|last = Cremins}}</ref> This also led to the Parlour Guides to Equitable Practice.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Parlour Guides to Equitable Practice Parlour|url = http://archiparlour.org/topics/parlour-guides-to-equitable-practice/|website = archiparlour.org|accessdate = 2015-11-14}}</ref>
== Architectural criticism == Architectural criticism by Stead has been published in a wide range of professional journals and magazines, including ''[[Architecture Australia]]'', ''Artichoke'', ''Monument'', ''Architecture Review Australia'', ''Pol Oxygen'' and ''[Inside] Australian Design Review''.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.australiandesignreview.com/?s=Naomi-Stead|title = Naomi Stead|date = |accessdate = |website = Australian Design Review|publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref><ref name=":1" /> She was a contributing editor to ''Architecture Australia'' from 2003 to 2012 and is a regular columnist for ''Places'' magazine.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|title = Naomi Stead|url = http://architectureau.com/contributors/Stead-Naomi/|website = ArchitectureAU|accessdate = 2015-11-14}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title = Naomi Stead {{!}} Places Journal|url = https://placesjournal.org/author/naomi-stead/|website = Places Journal|accessdate = 2015-11-14}}</ref> Stead has also written scholarly work on the history and future of architectural criticism and edited the anthology ''Semi-detached: Writing, representation and criticism in architecture (2012).''<ref>{{Cite book|title = Semi-detached : writing, representation and criticism in architecture / edited by Naomi Stead|url = http://catalogue.nla.gov.au/Record/6004492|publisher = Uro Media|date = 2012-01-01|location = Melbourne|isbn = 9780987228130|first = Naomi|last = Stead}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title = New Belle-Lettrism and the Future of Architectural Criticism|url = https://placesjournal.org/article/a-new-belle-lettrism-and-the-future-of-criticism/|website = Places Journal|accessdate = 2015-11-14}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|title = Critical Architecture|last = Stead|first = Naomi|publisher = Routledge|year = 2007|isbn = |location = London|pages = 76–8|chapter = Criticism in/and/of Crisis: The Australian Context}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title = The Judge is Not an Operator: Historiography, Criticality and Architectural Criticism|url = http://www.oasejournal.nl/en/Issues/69/TheJudgeIsNotAnOperatorHistoriographyCriticalityAndArchitecturalCriticism#116|website = www.oasejournal.nl|accessdate = 2015-11-14|last = Stead|first = Naomi|last2 = Macarthur|first2 = John|month = |year = 2009}}</ref>
== Contributions to public and academic culture == Stead contributes to public and academic culture in a range of ways. She is an expert member of the National Committee for Gender Equity of the [[Australian Institute of Architects]].<ref>{{Cite web|title = National Committee for Gender Equity - Parlour|url = http://archiparlour.org/national-committee-for-gender-equity/|website = archiparlour.org|accessdate = 2015-11-14}}</ref> She has edited academic journals, including ''Culture Unbound: Journal of Current Cultural Research'',with Prof Johan Fornas and Dr Martin Fredriksson;<ref>{{Cite web|title = Home {{!}} Culture Unbound|url = http://www.cultureunbound.ep.liu.se/|website = www.cultureunbound.ep.liu.se|accessdate = 2015-11-14}}</ref> ''Architectural Theory Review,'' with Dr Lee Stickells and Prof Michael Tawa (2011 – 2014), and was on the Executive Committee of the Society of Architectural Historians of Australia and New Zealand ([[SAHANZ]]) from 2003 to 2005.
Stead has also convened and co-convened a number of conferences. These include: * The Art of Drying: Practices and Aesthetics symposium, [[University of Queensland Art Museum]], 27 March 2015 (with [[Kelly Greenop]] and Allison Holland)<ref>{{Cite web|title = Hung Out to Dry|url = http://www.architecture.uq.edu.au/hung-out-to-dry|website = University of Queensland School of Architecture|accessdate = 2015-11-14|date = }}</ref> * Transform: Altering the Future of Architecture, 30 May 2013 (with Justine Clark and Karen Burns)<ref>{{Cite web|title = Transform: Altering the Future of Architecture - Parlour|url = http://archiparlour.org/transform/|website = archiparlour.org|accessdate = 2015-11-14}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title = Transform: Altering the Future of Architecture|url = http://architectureau.com/articles/transform-altering-the-future-of-architecture-1/|website = ArchitectureAU|accessdate = 2015-11-14|date = 31 October 2013|last = Kalms|first = Nikki}}</ref> * Lost in Conversation: Constructing the Oral History of Modern Architecture, 1 November 2013 (with Janina Gosseye, Naomi Stead and Deborah van der Plaat)<ref>{{Cite web|title = Lost in Conversation|url = https://lostinconversationconference.wordpress.com/|website = Lost in Conversation|accessdate = 2015-11-14|language = en-US}}</ref> * Writing Architecture II: A Symposium on Innovations in the Textual and Visual Critique of Buildings, [[Queensland Gallery of Modern Art]] and the [[State Library of Queensland]], 22–23 July 2010<ref>{{Cite web|title = Writing Architecture: A Symposium on Innovations in the Textual and Visual Critique of Buildings|url = http://iawis.org/writing-architecture-a-symposium-on-innovations-in-the-textual-and-visual-critique-of-buildings/|website = IAWIS/AIERTI|accessdate = 2015-11-14|language = en-US}}</ref> * Writing Architecture: A Symposium on Architectural Criticism and the Written Representation of Architecture, [[Institute for Modern Art]], Brisbane, 15 & 16 Aug 2009 * Queer Space: Centres and Peripheries a trans-disciplinary international conference on sexuality and space, University of Technology Sydney, February 2007.
Stead also regularly speaks at public and professional events on architecture and the built environment and has done a number of radio interviews.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Spotlight on gender inequality in architecture|url = http://www.abc.net.au/radionational/programs/blueprintforliving/women-in-architecture/6604468|website = Radio National|accessdate = 2015-11-14|language = en-AU}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title = The Conversation: Naomi Stead|url = http://www.abc.net.au/radionational/programs/bydesign/the-conversation---naomi-stead/4409420|website = Radio National|accessdate = 2015-11-14|language = en-AU}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title = The Plan – Rachel Hurst & Dr Naomi Stead|url = https://radio.adelaide.edu.au/the-plan-rachel-hurst-dr-naomi-stead/|website = Radio Adelaide|accessdate = 2015-11-14|language = en-US}}</ref>
== Exhibitions == Stead has curated a number of architectural exhibitions: * 2015. ''Portraits of Practice: At Work in Architecture'', Tin Sheds Gallery, Sydney, 11 July- Sept 11, 2015. In collaboration with Justine Clark, Maryam Gusheh, Fiona Young and Gill Matthewson.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Portraits of Practice - Parlour|url = http://archiparlour.org/portraits-of-practice/|website = archiparlour.org|accessdate = 2015-11-14}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title = New Parlour exhibition features women in architecture at work {{!}} Architecture And Design|url = http://www.architectureanddesign.com.au/news/new-photo-exhibition-to-feature-women-in-architect|website = Architecture And Design|accessdate = 2015-11-14}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title = Portraits of Practice|url = https://theredandblackarchitect.wordpress.com/2015/07/13/phuong-le-reviews-portraits-of-practice/|website = The Red and Black Architect|accessdate = 2015-11-14|first = Phuong|last = Le|first2 = |last2 = }}</ref> * 2015. ''Hung Out to Dry: Space, memory, and domestic laundry practices'', University of Queensland Art Museum, 21 March – 10 May 2015. In collaboration with Allison Holland and Kelly Greenop.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Hung out to dry - UQ Art Museum - The University of Queensland, Australia|url = http://www.artmuseum.uq.edu.au/content/hung-out-dry|website = www.artmuseum.uq.edu.au|accessdate = 2015-11-14}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title = Hung Out To Dry: the exhibition|url = http://www.architecture.uq.edu.au/hung-out-to-dry|website = School of Architecture|accessdate = 2015-11-14}}</ref> * 2010 ''Documentation: The Visual Sociology of Architects'', at Extra/Ordinary the national conference of the Australian Institute of Architects, Creative Director Melanie Dodds, Sydney, 22–24 April 2010. In collaboration with Dr [[Sandra Kaji-O'Grady|Sandra Kaji-O’Grady]] and Dr Kate Sweetapple.<ref>{{Cite journal|url = http://architectureau.com/articles/conference-7/|title = The Visual Sociology of Architects|last = Stead|first = Naomi|date = 2010|journal = Architecture Australia|doi = |pmid = |access-date = 14 November 2015|issue = 4|volume = 99}}</ref> * 2009 ''Mapping Sydney: Experimental Cartography and the Imagined City'', DAB LAB Research gallery UTS Faculty of Design Architecture and Building.<ref>{{Cite journal|url = http://architectureau.com/articles/exhibitions-1/|title = Mapping Sydney|last = Stickells|first = Lee|date = 2009|journal = Architecture Australia|doi = |pmid = |access-date = 14 November 2015|volume = 98|issue = 8}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|title = Mapping Sydney: Experimental Cartography and the Imagined City|last = Stead|first = Naomi|publisher = Local Consumption Publications|year = 2009|isbn = |location = Sydney|pages = }}</ref>
== Selected publications == * 2015 Naomi Stead, ‘Lest: In Order Not That,’ ''Mongrel Rapture: the Work of Ashton Raggatt Macdougall'', Uro, Melbourne, 2015. * 2014 Naomi Stead ed., ‘Dossier’, ''Architecture Australia'', vol 103, no 5, Sept/Oct 2014, pp. 53–69. * 2014 Naomi Stead ed., ''Women, Practice, Architecture,'' Routledge, London, July 2014. * 2013 Naomi Stead and Cristina Garduno Freeman, ‘Reception,’ ''Architectural Theory Review'', vol 18, no 3, December 2013. * 2012 Naomi Stead ed., "Resigned Accommodation" and "Usurpatory Strategies", ''Architectural Theory Review'', vol 17 no 2/3, August/December 2012. * 2012 Naomi Stead ed., ''Semi-Detached: Writing, Representation and Criticism in Architecture'', Uro: Melbourne, May 2012. * 2011 Naomi Stead, Lee Stickells and Michael Tawa, ‘Fifteen Years of Architectural Theory Review: New Beginnings,’ special issue, ''Architectural Theory Review'', vol 16, issue 2, 2011. * 2007 Naomi Stead and Jason Prior eds., Proceedings of the international conference [http://www.dab.uts.edu.au/conferences/queer_space/proceedings/ Queer Space: Centres and Peripheries], University of Technology Sydney, February 2007 * 2012 John Macarthur & Naomi Stead, ‘Aesthetics/Art/Pleasure’ in Sibel Bozdogan, Stephen Cairns, Greig Crysler and Hilde Heynen eds., ''Handbook of Architectural Theory'', Berg, Oxford, 123-135. * 2009 Naomi Stead, ‘Avoidance: On Some Euphemisms for the ‘Smallest Room’’ in Olga Gershenson and Barbara Penner eds, ''Ladies and Gents: Public Toilets and Gender'', Temple University Press, Philadelphia, 2009, pp. 126-132. * 2008 Naomi Stead, ‘Buildings, Photographs, Sculptures: On Medium and Disciplinarity in the work of the Bechers’, in Andrew Leach and John Macarthur eds., ''Architecture, Disciplinarity and Art'', A & S Books, Ghent, pp. 135–149. * 2007 Naomi Stead, ‘In the Mind of the Architect’: Architecture, Representation and Authorship in Documentary Film’, in ''Architecture and Authorship'', Tim Anstey, Katja Grillner & Rolf Hughes eds., Black Dog Press, London, pp. 50–59. * 2007 Naomi Stead, ‘Criticism in/and/of Crisis: The Australian Context’, in Jane Rendell, Mark Dorrian et al., eds., ''Critical Architecture'', [[Routledge Taylor & Francis Group|Routledge]], London and New York, pp. 76–83. * 2007 Naomi Stead, ‘Museological Landscapes, Mythological Lands: The Garden of Australian Dreams’, in Michael J. Ostwald and Steven Fleming eds. ''Museum, Gallery and Cultural Architecture in'' ''Australia, New Zealand and the Pacific Region: Essays on Antipodean Identity'', [[Edwin Mellen Press]], Wales, 2007, pp. 69–80. * 2006 John Macarthur and Naomi Stead, ‘The National Museum of Australia as Danse Macabre: Baroque Allegories of the Popular’, in ''South Pacific Museums: Beyond the New Museology?'' Chris Healy and Andrea Witcomb eds., [[Macquarie University]] ePress.
== Awards == * 2015 Shortlisted for Royal Institute of British Architects (RIBA) President’s Awards for Research, for the Parlour Guides to Equitable Practice, (in collaboration with Justine Clark and others).<ref>{{Cite web|url = https://www.architecture.com/RIBA/Contactus/NewsAndPress/PressReleases/2015/RIBAannounce2015shortlistsforPresidentsAwardsforResearch.aspx|title = RIBA Announce 2015 Shortlists for President's Awards for Research|date = 21 July 2015|accessdate = 14 November 2015|website = RIBA|publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref> * 2015 Adrian Ashton Prize, presented to Parlour: Women, Equity, Architecture, by the New South Wales Chapter of the Australian Institute of Architects (in collaboration with Justine Clark and others). * 2015 Bates Smart Award for Architecture in the Media (National Award) awarded to Parlour: Women, Equity, Architecture, at the Victorian Architecture Awards, Australian Institute of Architects Victorian Chapter (in collaboration with Justine Clark and others). * 2015 Shortlisted as Creative Director of the Australian Pavilion at the 2016 [[Venice Biennale of Architecture|Venice Architecture Biennale]], for ParlourLIVE!, with Justine Clark, [[Catherine Griffiths]], [[Maryam Gusheh]] and Fiona Young.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Australia’s shortlist of 2016 Venice Biennale pavilion proposals|url = http://www.bustler.net/index.php/article/australias_shortlist_of_2016_venice_biennale_proposals|website = Bustler|accessdate = 2015-11-14}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title = Parlour LIVE! - Parlour|url = http://archiparlour.org/parlour-live/|website = archiparlour.org|accessdate = 2015-11-14}}</ref> * 2008 Adrian Ashton Prize for Architectural Writing, presented by the New South Wales Chapter of the Australian Institute of Architects.
== References == {{Reflist}}
== External links == * Personal website http://naomistead.com/ * University of Queensland website http://researchers.uq.edu.au/researcher/636
{{authority control}}

{{Unreferenced|date=December 2009}} [[Image:GSMTCNY44.JPG|thumb|New York Center for Independent Publishing]] '''The New York Center for Independent Publishing''' is located on New York's "Literary Row" at 20 West 44th Street in Midtown Manhattan. Formerly the Small Press Center, the Center was founded by Whitney North Seymour, Jr. in 1984. The Center's historical seedbed as the home of independent publishing dates back to 1831, when [[James Harper (publisher)|James Harper]], one of the original four Harper Brothers, joined as a member of the [[General Society of Mechanics and Tradesmen of the City of New York]], which has housed the Center since its inception. Other early printer and publisher members include [[John Bishop Putnam]], James J. Little and Benjamin Collins.
The Center provides access to education and expertise in the field of independent publishing, networking opportunities, workshops, teleseminars, lectures, its annual small press book fair and exhibits. The Center also houses [[The Crouse Library for Publishing Arts]], a comprehensive collection of books (many rare and out of print) and other materials on the bookselling and publishing industries.
The Center's annual signature programs include: the Independent and Small Press Book Fair; National Small Press Month, and its host of reading marathons, lectures, and publishing workshops; the New York Round Table Writers’ Conference; and the series, Emerging Voices: Writers Published by Groundbreaking Independent Presses. In addition to such public programs, each year the Center awards the coveted Poor Richard Award to an independent Publisher who has made an outstanding contribution to the field of independent publishing. Past recipients include: [[Barney Rosset]], [[André Schiffrin]], Peter Workman, Esther Margolis and Bill Henderson.
The Center is an educational program of the [[General Society of Mechanics and Tradesmen of the City of New York]], located at 20 West 44th Street, between 5th and 6th Avenues in midtown Manhattan.
==External links== * [http://www.nycip.org New York Center for Independent Publishing] * [http://www.smallpressmonth.org Small Press Month]

{{Unreferenced|date=December 2007}} A '''Nomadic bag''' is a bag woven by various [[nomadic]] tribes of the [[Middle East]] and [[Central Asia]] for utilitarian and decorative purposes.
The nomadic tribes of the Middle East and Central Asia are perhaps more known for the hand knotted [[carpets]] and hand woven [[kilim]]s (flatwoven textiles) that they made. These tribes include but are not limited to the [[Baloch people|Baloch]], the [[Turkmen people|Turkmen]], the [[Afshar tribe|Afshars]], the [[Bakhtyari]], the [[Qashqai people|Qashqai]], the [[Kurds]] and many others. The bags that they wove were done in the same techniques as the larger rugs they also made. The most common technique is [[Persian Carpet|hand-knotted pile]], but many tribal bags were also done in the various flat woven techniques including [[plain weave]] ([[kilim]] weave), soumac technique and other less common techniques.
These bags were used for various purposes. Often they were used for transporting goods while on migration. They also served as storage containers to be used in the tent or [[yurt]]. There are also specialized bags such as bags for carrying mirrors, bags for carrying the [[Qur'an]], bags for carrying tent stakes and more. Often the bags are known by specific names based on the function they served. Some common bag names are "cuval" ([[camel]] bag), "khorjin" (double-sided [[donkey]] bags) and "mafrash" (bedding bag) to name just a few.
Often, the back panel of a bag will have little or no design. Generally on bags with knotted pile faces, the back of the bag will be executed in a plain woven [[kilim]] technique.
Although there are still some tribal weavers weaving nice bags, it is the antique bags and bag faces that are the most prized and the most collected.
==Bag face== From the [[collecting|collector]]s point of view, the front or the ''face'' of the bag is much more interesting and more collectible. Often, with antique bags, the backs of the bag have been separated and discarded at some point and only the bagface remains.
==See also== *[[Persian rug]]
{{Bags|state=collapsed}}
[[Category:Central Asian culture]] [[Category:Woven fabrics]] [[Category:Textile arts]]
{{textile-arts-stub}} {{CAsia-stub}}

[[File:Omphalos museum.jpg|thumb|upright|The omphalos in the museum of [[Delphi]]]] [[File:Outside Omphalos at Delphi.jpg|thumb|The omphalos stone displayed outside at Delphi, Greece]] The '''Omphalos of Delphi''' is an ancient marble monument that was found at the archaeological site of [[Delphi]], [[Greece]].
==Mythology== The omphalos represents the stone which [[Rhea (mythology)|Rhea]] wrapped in swaddling clothes, pretending it was Zeus, in order to deceive [[Cronus]].
==Description== Among the [[Ancient Greeks]], it was a widespread belief that Delphi was the center of the world. According to the myths regarding the founding of the [[Pythia|Delphic Oracle]], [[Zeus]], in his attempt to locate the center of the earth, launched two eagles from the two ends of the world, and the eagles, starting simultaneously and flying at equal speed, crossed their paths above the area of Delphi. From this point, Zeus threw a stone from the sky to see where it will fall. The stone fell at Delphi, which since then was considered to be the center of the world, the omphalos – "navel of the earth". Indeed, the same stone thrown by Zeus took the same name and became the symbol of Apollo, the sacred Oracle and more generally of the region of Delphi.
The marble-carved stone which constituted the omphalos in the monument with the tripod and the dancers troubled the excavators, because they could not decide if it was the original or a copy from Hellenistic and Roman times. In the 2nd century A.D., [[Pausanias (geographer)|Pausanias]] traveled to the area of Delphi and has provided us with rare evidence through his work. The stone of the omphalos seems to have been decorated in high relief and had an oval shape. It is possible that in ancient times it was covered by a mesh of wool cloth and it was kept in the adyton (inner sanctum), beside the tripod and the daphne (bay leaves), the other sacred symbols of the god. As described by Pausanias, within the woolen cloth that was wound around the stone there were precious stones designed in the shape of a mermaid, while two gilded eagles were fixed on top of it.
Recent studies by French archaeologists have demonstrated that the omphalos and the columns are connected and interlocked. In other words, the stone navel was mounted on the bronze tripods supported by the three dancers, at the top of the column. This is the spot where the omphalos is thought to have been placed till today, as a cover of the column, in order to symbolically supplement the meaning and importance of the Athenian votive offering. The Athenians, wanting to placate and honor the goddess of light, offered him this copy of the original stone, which combined both delphic symbols as a gift from the hands of the three priestess figures of Athenian origin.<ref name=A>[http://odysseus.culture.gr/h/4/gh430.jsp?obj_id=4687 Μόνιμη Έκθεση Αρχαιολογικού Μουσείου Δελφών: Ομφαλός.]</ref><ref>Ροζίνα Κολώνια, ''Το Αρχαιολογικό Μουσείο Δελφών'', Αθήνα, Υπουργείο Πολιτισμού – Ταμείο Αρχαιολογικών πόρων και Απαλλοτριώσεων, 2009, 60 – 62.</ref><ref>Πάνος Βαλαβάνης, ''Ιερά και Αγώνες στην Αρχαία Ελλάδα. Ολυμπία – Δελφοί – Ίσθμια – Νέμεα – Αθήνα'', Αθήνα, 2004, 244.</ref>
==See also== * [[Omphalos]]
==References== {{reflist}}
== External links == {{Commons category-inline|Delphi Omphalos}} *[http://odysseus.culture.gr/h/4/eh430.jsp?obj_id=4687 "Omphalos" in the Archaeological Museum of Delphi, Greek Ministry of Culture and Sports]
[[Category:Delphi|Omphalos]] [[Category:Ancient Greek art]]

'''Reel Women Media''' is a [[filmmaking]] [[non-profit organization]] in [[Austin, Texas]], USA, that provides support to women in the [[film industry]].
[[Ally Acker]] coined the term Reel Women in 1984 for her book ''Reel Women: Pioneers of the Cinema, 1896 to Present'' and documentary series. This was the first production in the market that revealed the transformative roles women had within the film industry that were not as widely recognized by prior film history studies.
Reel Women began in 1995<ref>Robinson, Will. [http://www.austinchronicle.com/screens/2002-04-26/85729/ "Reel Women Host Movie Hoot"].''Austin Chronicle''. </ref> as an collective of women media-makers who were helping each other out on film projects.<ref name="Macor2010">{{cite book|author=Alison Macor|title=Chainsaws, Slackers, and Spy Kids: Thirty Years of Filmmaking in Austin, Texas|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=eBQ_FGDKiSkC&pg=PA309|date=22 February 2010|publisher=University of Texas Press|isbn=978-0-292-77829-0|pages=309–}}</ref> From there it grew into an organization of about 700 people, both men and women, young and old, anywhere from amateur to professional. Reel Women serves as a resource to the film community over the years by planning guest speakers, workshops,<ref>[http://www.klru.org/austinnow/archives/reel_women/reel_women.php "KLRU: Austin Now > Spotlight report: Reel Women"]. </ref> mixers, and screening events.<ref>[http://www.austinchronicle.com/screens/1999-10-15/74282/ "Reel Women Shorts"]. ''Austin Chronicle''.</ref><ref>[http://www.austinchronicle.com/screens/2001-08-31/82856/ "The Female Gaze Reel Women's Digital Divas"]. By Kimberley Jones, ''Austin Chronicle''. Aug. 31, 2001</ref> Its members worked with other non-profit organizations in Austin, including the [[Austin Film Society]], The Austin Creative Alliance, Austin Film Meet, Picturebox Productions, and [[SXSW Film Festival]].<ref>[http://archive.constantcontact.com/fs047/1101335548948/archive/1102568273971.html ""Saving Evan White" premieres at SXSW and more! "]. ''Women in Film and Television''.</ref>
Reel Women also took part directly in filmmaking by organizing film shoots and planning filming projects, <ref>Jones, Kimberly. [http://www.austinchronicle.com/daily/screens/2011-04-29/slacker-tk/ "Restyling 'Slacker'"]. ''Austin Chronicle''.</ref> as well as making their own educational films and books. These include the ''[[Filmmakers on Film]]'' 10-Disc DVD set and Ally Acker's films ''Reel Herstory with Jodie Foster'' (2014) and ''Flowering Little Crone'', as well as the books ''Reel Women: Pioneers of the Cinema, The First Hundred Years'', ''Volume 1 and Volume 2''.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.reelwomen.com/untitled-c20kp|title=reelwomen|website=reelwomen|access-date=2016-12-13}}</ref> Reel Women was the local sponsor for the [[48 Hour Film Project]],<ref>Rosenblatt, Josh. [http://www.austinchronicle.com/screens/2007-07-06/499248/ "Coming Next Week"]. ''Austin Chronicle''.</ref><ref>[http://amfmstudiosnews.com/austin-film-and-arts-academy-serves-up-summer-classes-for-aspiring-filmmakers/ "AUSTIN FILM AND ARTS ACADEMY SERVES UP SUMMER CLASSES FOR ASPIRING FILMMAKERS"]. ''AM FM Studios Magazine''. </ref> a competition to make the best short film in only 48 hours using predetermined elements.<ref>O'Connell, Joe. [http://www.austinchronicle.com/screens/2008-05-09/621814/ "Film News"]. ''Austin Chronicle''. </ref><ref>[http://www.austinchronicle.com/screens/2007-07-13/501942/ "Adjusting to the Mise-en-Scène"]. ''Austin Chronicle''.</ref>
Reel Women also organized [[LUNAFEST]],<ref>[http://www.austinchronicle.com/screens/2004-11-12/237324/ "Quick, Good, and Good for You"]. ''Austin Chronicle''.</ref><ref>[http://www.slackerwood.com/node/1685 "Reel Women Brings Lunafest to Austin"]. ''Slackerwood''</ref> a traveling film festival with films for, about and by women.<ref>[http://www.boiseweekly.com/Cobweb/archives/2010/04/19/lunafest-comes-out-west "LUNAFEST Comes Out West"] By Jeremiah Robert Wierenga ''Boise Weekly''.</ref> Reel Women also organized the Austin Film Industry Holiday party in December that served as its yearly fundraising event.
Continuing on today, Reel Women is a full service facility that provides pro bono editing services to clients with educational projects. Their current clientele include, [[Today (U.S. TV program)|NBC's ''Today Show'']], ABC's ''[[Good Morning America]]'', [[National Geographic (magazine)|National Geographic]]'s ''Explorer'', [[Lifetime (TV network)|Lifetime]], and [[The Walt Disney Company|Disney]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.reelwomen.com/collections|title=reelwomen|website=reelwomen|access-date=2016-12-13}}</ref>
== References == {{Reflist|30em}}
==External links== {{portal|Film}} * [https://www.imdb.com/news/ni2613231/ Reel Women Brings Lunafest to Austin]. [[Internet Movie Database|IMDB]]. * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=unLr2Q_GmpY YouTube] * [http://www.48hourfilm.com/austin/ The Austin 48 Hour Film Project]
